study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the accuracy of positioning custom 3D printed titanium acetabular implants in patients with large acetabular defects and assess clinical outcomes, including walking status.
results_summary: The study found that all custom implants were positioned within 10 mm of the planned center of rotation, with 95% not rotated more than 10° from the plan. Walking status was a secondary outcome, but specific results related to walking were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 20 patients (13 females, 7 males) with large acetabular defects, mean age 66 years, mean BMI 28.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance of waist-mounted sensor algorithms for detecting gait events during walking in adults.
results_summary: The study identified 15 algorithms for gait event detection, with most showing an absolute error of 50-100 ms in healthy adults. However, accuracy decreased at lower gait speeds, and few algorithms were validated in patients with neurological diseases.
population_specificity: Adults (mean age: 44.0 years), including healthy individuals and some patients with neurological diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term outcomes of primary stent placement for superficial femoral artery (SFA) lesions in patients with claudication, focusing on freedom from target lesion revascularization and improvements in walking ability and quality of life.
results_summary: The study found sustained freedom from clinically driven target lesion revascularization (75.4% at 36 months), significant improvements in ankle-brachial index (ABI) and Rutherford scores, and notable increases in Walking Impairment Questionnaire (WIQ) scores, indicating improved walking ability. Stent fracture rates were low (2.0%).
population_specificity: Patients with atherosclerotic lesions in the superficial femoral artery (SFA) and claudication (64.4% male; mean age 69.3 ± 10.1 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of weight-supported treadmill training in critically ill patients during and after ICU stay on time to independent functional ambulation.
results_summary: The study compares bodyweight-supported treadmill training (BWSTT) with conventional physiotherapy, measuring outcomes like time to functional ambulation, walking distance, muscle strength, and post-traumatic stress symptoms. Results will contribute to understanding early physiotherapy interventions for critically ill patients.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients in ICUs who were mechanically ventilated for at least 48 hours, able to follow instructions, and met safety criteria for physical exercise.
effective_dosage: 40 minutes of physiotherapy daily (BWSTT or conventional) in one or two sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effectiveness of therapeutic footwear as an intervention for mobility impairment in children.
results_summary: The review found limited fair-quality evidence that corrective footwear may assist in reducing deformity in congenital talipes equino varus but has no significant effect on pes planus. Functional footwear showed alterations in biomechanical parameters for mobile pes planus and cerebral palsy, though psychosocial outcomes were minimally analyzed.
population_specificity: Children aged 9 months to 18 years with mobility impairments, including congenital talipes equino varus, mobile pes planus, and cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether balloon pulmonary angioplasty (BPA) improved quality of life (QOL) in patients with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH).
results_summary: The study found that BPA significantly improved QOL scores (from 0.741 to 0.802) and hemodynamic measures (mPAP and pulmonary vascular resistance) in CTEPH patients, particularly in the domain of "usual activities."
population_specificity: Japanese patients with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the characteristics and outcomes of therapeutic walking programs for menopausal women, identifying features linked to successful symptom reduction and long-term wellness.
results_summary: The review found that 91% of walking programs showed beneficial outcomes in at least one menopause-related issue, though data on vasomotor symptoms and sleep problems were limited. Walking interventions varied in duration (4 weeks to 3 years) and frequency (average 3.8 times per week).
population_specificity: Menopausal women (in transition or postmenopausal).
effective_dosage: Average weekly frequency of 3.8 ± 1.8 sessions (specific duration per session not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate adherence to physical activity, including walking, among organ transplant recipients and candidates to promote active lifestyles.
results_summary: The study found that 44% of respondents had a sedentary lifestyle, while others engaged in physical activities like walking, cycling, or sports. Walking was one of the activities practiced, but adherence varied among transplant candidates and recipients.
population_specificity: Organ transplant recipients (kidney and liver) and candidates on waiting lists.
effective_dosage: At least 3 to 40 minutes, 2 to 3 times per week (for physical activity, including walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vertical current steering (vCS) improves ambulation in Parkinson's disease patients compared to conventional single-contact stimulation.
results_summary: vCS significantly reduced total electrical energy delivered (TEED) but did not show differences in functional ambulation performance (FAP) scores compared to single-contact stimulation. However, vCS achieved higher FAP scores with lower TEED, indicating improved efficiency.
population_specificity: Seven levodopa-responsive Parkinson's disease patients.
effective_dosage: vCS divisions of 70%/30% and 50%/50%, compared to single-contact stimulation with four therapeutic window amplitudes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of post-caesarean elastic abdominal binder use on recovery, including post-operative pain, mobility, and quality of life.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in pain scores, six-minute walking distance, quality-of-life dimensions, overall health status, or post-operative complications between the abdominal binder and control groups. The positive effects of the elastic abdominal binder could not be demonstrated.
population_specificity: Pregnant women undergoing caesarean delivery (180 participants: 90 in the abdominal binder group, 90 in the control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Anterior controllable antidisplacement and fusion (ACAF) surgery in treating extensive cervico-thoracic OPLL and its impact on walking and neurological function.
results_summary: The study found that ACAF surgery improved neurological symptoms immediately, restored spinal canal cross-section, and enabled the patient to stand and walk without assistance within 6 months, with full recovery of bladder and bowel function by 15 months.
population_specificity: A 45-year-old male with extensive cervico-thoracic OPLL (C2-T2) and severe walking disturbance.

study_goal: To assess the effect of biomechanical footwear therapy versus control footwear on pain and physical function in individuals with symptomatic knee osteoarthritis over 24 weeks.
results_summary: Biomechanical footwear significantly improved knee pain, physical function, stiffness, and global scores compared to control footwear at 24 weeks, with fewer serious adverse events in the biomechanical group (2.7% vs. 8.3%). The clinical importance of these improvements remains uncertain.
population_specificity: 220 participants (mean age 65.2 years, 47.3% women) with symptomatic, radiologically confirmed knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a newly developed portable oxygen concentrator with auto-DODS compared to conventional DODS in improving oxygenation during rest and walking in patients with respiratory conditions.
results_summary: The study compared auto-DODS and conventional DODS in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or interstitial pneumonia, measuring oxygen saturation, walking distance, and other physiological and subjective outcomes during a 6-minute walk test. Results will be presented at conferences and submitted for peer review, but specific findings are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or interstitial pneumonia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acceptance, safety, and effectiveness of exercise interventions, including walking, in solid organ transplant (SOT) candidates.
results_summary: The study found that exercise training, including walking, was safe and acceptable for SOT candidates, with no reported adverse events. While some studies showed improvements in exercise capacity (e.g., 6-minute walking distance) and quality of life, the overall findings were inconsistent, with a lack of significant results in most randomized controlled trials.
population_specificity: Solid organ transplant (SOT) candidates

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the stability of one-stage bilateral Salter pelvic osteotomy for treating bilateral developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) in children of walking age.
results_summary: The study found that both unilateral and bilateral Salter osteotomy disrupted pelvic ring integrity but showed no significant differences in stability metrics (sacroiliac joint stability, local stability, ultimate load, axial stiffness). Bilateral osteotomy was deemed viable and stable for children with bilateral DDH.
population_specificity: Child cadavers aged 2-6 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of functional electric stimulation (FES) combined with postural correction on gait and balance in multiple sclerosis patients, comparing it to individual physiotherapy.
results_summary: Group 1 (FES with postural correction) showed immediate improvements in balance and self-perception, with persistent and delayed effects in some measures. Group 2 (physiotherapy) also showed immediate improvements in balance and daily life aspects, with some effects surpassing Group 1.
population_specificity: Forty-four subjects with multiple sclerosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the physiological benefits of bamboo forest therapy, including walking, on university students' blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation.
results_summary: The study found that a three-day bamboo forest therapy session, including walking, significantly decreased blood pressure and heart rate while increasing peripheral oxygen saturation. Bamboo forest environments provided better sensory and physiological benefits compared to urban settings.
population_specificity: 120 university students (60 males and 60 females) aged 19-24.
effective_dosage: 15 minutes of viewing the landscape in the morning and 15 minutes of walking in the afternoon.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and kinematic outcomes of ankle arthroplasty combined with subtalar arthrodesis in patients with severe ankle and subtalar arthritis.
results_summary: Clinical scores and passive ankle mobility improved postoperatively, but normalized walking speed and stride length remained lower than healthy controls. Sagittal-plane foot joint mobility was about 50% of healthy joints, with compensation via increased frontal-plane motion at the tibiotalar joint.
population_specificity: Twenty-three patients with severe ankle and subtalar arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a 4-week perturbation-based treadmill training on daily-life dynamic gait stability and fall risk in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that perturbation-based treadmill training improved balance recovery strategies and reduced laboratory falls, but its translation to daily-life gait stability and fall risk reduction remains under investigation.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 65+ living in the community with an elevated risk of falling.
effective_dosage: Two times per week for 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of combined physical and cognitive training on fall rate and risks of falling in older adults with mild cognitive impairment.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in fall incidence rate among groups post-intervention. However, dynamic balance improved with combined physical and cognitive training and cognitive training alone.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (aged 60-83) with mild cognitive impairment in Manila, Philippines.
effective_dosage: 60 to 90 minutes, one to three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the challenges faced by therapists and supervisors in delivering integrated motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy for individuals with bipolar disorder and alcohol misuse.
results_summary: The study identified key themes, including the importance of addressing avoidance behaviors, balancing shame and normalization of alcohol use, and discrepancies between clients' intentions and actual behavior regarding alcohol reduction.
population_specificity: Individuals with bipolar disorder and alcohol misuse.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the length of uniportal incision in VATS lobectomy affects postoperative pain and surgical outcomes, including the 6-Minute Walking Test.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in postoperative pain or walking test results between small and long incision groups, though the long incision reduced operative time without compromising outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing uniportal VATS lobectomy for Stage I lung cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the safety, feasibility, and user perception of the MAK exoskeleton for gait rehabilitation in stroke and multiple sclerosis patients, while testing different assistance algorithms.
results_summary: The MAK exoskeleton was used safely with no adverse effects, and Mode 3 showed better outcomes in gait tests compared to no device, though results were mixed in some participants. User perception of the device was moderately positive.
population_specificity: 4 stroke patients and 1 multiple sclerosis patient.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effects of EDTA chelation therapy versus placebo or no treatment on clinical outcomes in people with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in clinical outcomes such as mortality, myocardial infarction, angina, or stroke between EDTA chelation therapy and placebo. There was also no evidence of major or minor adverse events associated with the treatment.
population_specificity: Participants with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, including those with peripheral vascular disease and coronary artery disease (some post-myocardial infarction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of returning to work and health-related quality of life (HRQL) in cardiac rehabilitation patients, including the role of physical performance measures like 6-minute walking distance.
results_summary: The study found that physical performance, including walking distance, was less influential on HRQL and return to work compared to patient-reported psychosocial factors. High educational level and physical HRQL were associated with successful return to work.
population_specificity: Patients (54±7 years, 77% men) undergoing multi-component cardiac rehabilitation after cardiovascular events.
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated; follow-up was 6 months post-rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between patient factors (including mobility and function) at hospital admission and discharge destination in general medical patients.
results_summary: Patients discharged directly home had higher functional, mobility, and cognitive scores. Two models ("DEMMI and toilet transfers" and "AlphaFIM and walking independence") effectively differentiated between discharge home and not home, with good statistical validity.
population_specificity: General medical inpatients (median age 81 years, 53% female) admitted to a tertiary hospital and referred to physical therapy, excluding those from residential care.
study_duration: Data collected a median of 2 days from admission; study duration was July 2016 to August 2017.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of pharmacological agents (intravenous or oral) compared with placebo or other agents in patients with Buerger's disease.
results_summary: Intravenous iloprost was more effective than aspirin for ulcer healing and pain relief, but oral iloprost showed no significant benefit over placebo. Comparisons between prostacyclin and prostaglandin analogues showed no clear differences in outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with Buerger's disease (thromboangiitis obliterans).
effective_dosage: Iloprost 200 mcg and 400 mcg (oral), intravenous iloprost (dosage not specified).
study_duration: Outcomes measured at 28 days to 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of transtheoretical model-based walking exercise training and follow-up on exercise behavior and metabolic control in patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The intervention group showed increased scores in exercise change processes, decision-making balance, and self-efficacy scales compared to pre-test measurements, indicating improved exercise behavior and metabolic outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes (76 intervention and 76 control individuals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of social comparison standards on acute anxiety levels and phobic symptoms.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Walking's effects.
population_specificity: 159 individuals (no further details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of lung transplantation on diaphragmatic function using a multimodal approach.
results_summary: The study found a reduction in diaphragmatic function post-surgery, which persisted for 6 months but fully recovered after 1 year. Dysfunction was observed in terms of force, weakness, electrical activity, and kinematics, likely due to phrenic nerve injury from surgical procedures.
population_specificity: 30 patients undergoing lung transplantation for end-stage pulmonary disease.
study_duration: Pre-operatively, at discharge, and at 6 and 12 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the construct validity and test-retest reliability of the RUNZI® mobile application for assessing gait parameters in people with mild to moderate Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The RUNZI® app showed moderate to excellent correlation with the 10-meter walking test at fast speeds and excellent correlation for walking speed at comfortable speeds. Test-retest reliability was good to excellent for spatio-temporal gait parameters.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild to moderate Parkinson's disease (n=30).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness and safety of physical activity interventions, including walking, on the physical and mental health of individuals diagnosed with non-advanced colorectal cancer.
results_summary: The study found uncertain evidence that physical activity interventions improve physical function and no significant effect on disease-related mental health, but potential benefits for aerobic fitness, fatigue, and quality of life up to six months. Adverse events were minor where reported.
population_specificity: Adults with non-advanced colorectal cancer (T1-4 N0-2 M0), treated surgically or with neoadjuvant/adjuvant therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (varied by study, including walking, cycling, resistance exercise, yoga, and core stabilization).
study_duration: Most common duration was 12 weeks (7 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how visual dual-tasking (reading text and altered optical flow) affects walking speed, stability, and the relationship between mediolateral center of mass displacement and trunk movement in healthy adults.
results_summary: Visual dual-tasking increased walking speed and step length compared to single-tasking. Reading text while walking reduced step length variability and increased mediolateral center of mass displacement, linked to trunk inclination, indicating altered stability.
population_specificity: Nineteen able-bodied young adults.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking conditions, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a home-based exercise program (including walking via stationary cycling) on functional capacity, health-related quality of life, and disability in patients with systemic sclerosis.
results_summary: The study found that the home-based exercise program significantly improved walking distance (6-minute walk test), strength measures, physical component of quality of life (SF-36), and disability scores (HAQ-DI) compared to usual care.
population_specificity: Patients with systemic sclerosis (mean age ~63 years in the intervention group, ~62 years in the control group).
effective_dosage: Exercise on a stationary cycle and strengthening of upper limbs; stretching of the hands (specific frequency/duration not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of four different post-TKA rehabilitation interventions, including walking-related therapies, on patient outcomes such as walking speed and knee function.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in walking speed or KOOS scores across the four intervention groups, suggesting that all methods provided similar outcomes. Clinicians are advised to use the least expensive intervention since efficacy was comparable.
population_specificity: Primary unilateral TKA patients, average age 63, 61% female, 67% white, overweight (mean BMI 31.6), mostly with private insurance or Medicare.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of anxiety on vocational rehabilitation and its relationship with functional tests, including the 6-minute walking test, in patients after liver or kidney transplantation.
results_summary: The study found that state and trait anxiety negatively influenced perceived work ability and partially affected functional status, as evidenced by inverse relationships with the 30-second chair stand test results. Psychological factors significantly impacted working ability in post-transplant patients.
population_specificity: 100 patients after liver or kidney transplantation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of a pedometer app intervention in helping overweight adults achieve a daily walking goal of 10,000 steps.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased daily steps by an average of 4,806 steps, with strong statistical significance (P<.001), suggesting that structured goal-setting and follow-up can enhance physical activity in overweight adults.
population_specificity: Overweight adults (mean BMI 32.53 kg/m², n=98).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether different modes of biofeedback (audio, visual, or audiovisual) differentially affect anterior ground reaction force (AGRF) generation during walking in able-bodied and post-stroke individuals.
results_summary: All three biofeedback modes significantly increased peak AGRF in the targeted and paretic leg compared to no biofeedback, with no significant differences between modes. Able-bodied individuals showed greater stride-to-stride variation in AGRF during audio biofeedback, but this effect was not observed in post-stroke individuals.
population_specificity: Seven able-bodied individuals (6 females, 27±2 years) and nine post-stroke individuals (6 females, 54±12 years, 42±26 months post-stroke).
effective_dosage: Four 30-second walking trials per condition (no biofeedback, audio, visual, audiovisual).
study_duration: Single session with multiple short trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a HAPA-based planning intervention with tailored text messages could reduce workplace sitting time and increase non-sedentary behaviors like walking in office workers.
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced workplace sitting time and favored increased walking time, with statistically significant group-by-time interaction effects (p = .003).
population_specificity: Full-time office workers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and adherence of a dual-task training (DTT) program using the CMI-APP in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found high adherence (91%) to the DTT program, with participants perceiving it as somewhat difficult but enjoyable and valuable. The CMI-APP was deemed safe, usable, and motivating for DTT in people with MS.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (mean age 52.6 years, mean disease duration 9.4 years, mean Expanded Disability Status Scale score 3.6).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but 20 sessions were conducted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of combined tranexamic acid (TXA) and dexamethasone (DEX) for anti-inflammatory and clinical outcomes after total hip arthroplasty (THA), including pain levels during walking.
results_summary: The study found that the TXA + DEX group had lower pain scores during walking at 24 hours postoperatively compared to the TXA-only group. The combination also reduced postoperative fatigue and nausea/vomiting without increasing complications.
population_specificity: 100 patients undergoing primary unilateral total hip arthroplasty (THA).
effective_dosage: TXA at 15 mg/kg (repeated 3 hours postoperatively) and DEX at 20 mg.
study_duration: Intervention administered perioperatively, with outcomes measured up to 72 hours postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of long-term use of insoles with a toe-grip bar on balance, walking, and running in preschool children.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvement in 25m running time after wearing insoles with a toe-grip bar for 4 weeks, but other walking and balance parameters were not mentioned as significantly affected.
population_specificity: Preschool children (52 participants)
effective_dosage: Not specified (insoles worn during school hours)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether capacitive resistive radiofrequency therapy (RF) reduces perineal pain and discomfort, particularly while walking, after vaginal deliveries.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in pain scores between the RF and control groups, but RF was associated with less discomfort while walking and lower paracetamol consumption. Multivariate analysis confirmed the association between RF and reduced walking discomfort.
population_specificity: Women with perineal tears or episiotomies after vaginal delivery (instrumental assisted or not).
study_duration: Treatment administered on day 1 and day 2 postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of combining extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT) and dry needling (DN) on pain and functionality in patients with plantar fasciitis compared to ESWT alone.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of ESWT and DN significantly improved pain scores, maximum painless standing time, and walking distance compared to ESWT alone, though no differences were observed in pressure pain threshold or certain functionality subscales.
population_specificity: Forty patients clinically diagnosed with plantar fasciitis.
effective_dosage: 3 sessions of ESWT to plantar fascia and DN to trigger points in gastrosoleus muscles (for the ESWT-DN group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify barriers and enablers for older adults to engage in fall prevention activities, including walking, during the 6-month period post-hospital discharge.
results_summary: Reduced physical capability (fatigue, chronic pain, unsteadiness when walking) hindered safe return to daily activities, while tailored fall education improved knowledge and motivation. Access to therapy or social support enhanced recovery experiences compared to those without assistance.
population_specificity: Older adults recently discharged from hospital rehabilitation wards (n=30, subset of an RCT with n=390).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate a novel composite measure of active range of motion in adults with upper limb conditions using abobotulinumtoxinA.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the intervention.
population_specificity: Adults with upper limb conditions in tertiary rehabilitation centers in Australia, Europe, and the United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of daily active commuting (walking and cycling) on physical activity and exercise capacity in healthy hospital employees.
results_summary: Active commuting significantly improved exercise capacity compared to passive commuting, with notable differences in actively covered distances between groups. The intervention group showed a statistically significant increase in exercise capacity (P = .003, ES = 0.82).
population_specificity: Healthy hospital employees (age: 46 ± 9 years, 38% male) with predominantly passive commuting habits.
effective_dosage: 150 min/wk of moderate- to vigorous-intensity exercise during commute.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of robot-assisted gait training combined with virtual reality versus standard robot-assisted gait training on cognitive functions and walking endurance in patients with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The study found that robot-assisted gait training with virtual reality significantly improved walking endurance (2-Minutes Walk Test) and executive functions, with gains maintained at one-month follow-up. Both groups showed improved quality of life, but the virtual reality group had larger positive effects on gait ability.
population_specificity: Outpatients with multiple sclerosis (n=17).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to define meaningful changes in the 6-minute walk distance for people with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD) by correlating changes in walk distance with participant-reported improvements or declines in walking ability.
results_summary: The study found that among people with PAD, improvements of ~8 and ~20 meters in the 6-minute walk distance represented small and large improvements in walking ability, respectively. Participants who reported no change in walking ability still experienced a mean decline of 7 meters in the 6-minute walk test over one year.
population_specificity: People with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD), mean age 71.2 ± 8.8 years.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (observational study, no dosage administered).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a herbal medicine foot bath decoction (FBD) for diabetic foot infection (DFI) and explore its mechanism, including effects on walking speed and distance.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a planned evaluation of walking speed and distance as secondary efficacy indicators, but no results are provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: 60 participants with diabetic foot infection (DFI).
study_duration: Weekly evaluations during the intervention (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-flow oxygen therapy (HFOT) during exercise training was more effective than standard oxygen therapy (V-mask) in improving exercise capacity, particularly walking distance, in patients with hypoxemic COPD.
results_summary: Exercise training improved exercise capacity in both groups, with HFOT showing a statistically significant greater improvement in 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) but not in endurance time (Tlim). Patient satisfaction was similar between groups.
population_specificity: 171 patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and chronic hypoxemia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise training involved 20 supervised sessions).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated (20 supervised sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of deep dry needling on lower limb dysfunction, including walking and standing, in poststroke spastic patients.
results_summary: Deep dry needling reduced muscle spasticity and improved lower limb function and gait speed in poststroke survivors, as measured by the Modified Modified Ashworth Scale and functional tests.
population_specificity: Poststroke survivors with spasticity (71% male; mean age 57 ± 10 years).
study_duration: 1 week (3 sessions) with follow-up at 1 month post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether distal femoral and talar cartilage thicknesses differed in poliomyelitis patients compared to healthy controls, focusing on walking biomechanics.
results_summary: The study found that distal femoral cartilage was thinner on the more affected side in poliomyelitis patients compared to both their less affected side and healthy controls. Talar cartilage was also thinner in patients compared to controls, with quadriceps strength correlating positively with femoral cartilage thickness and knee pain correlating negatively with talar cartilage thickness.
population_specificity: Thirty-six poliomyelitis patients (12 males, 24 females) and 36 age, gender, and BMI-matched healthy controls (11 males, 25 females).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether staff-directed facilitation of early mobilization (walking) improves postoperative pulmonary function and reduces 30-day pulmonary complications after colorectal surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in recovery of pulmonary function or reduction in postoperative pulmonary complications between the facilitated mobilization group and the usual care group.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing colorectal surgery (median age 63, 57% male, 80% laparoscopic).
effective_dosage: Not specified (staff-assisted transfers and walking during hospital stay).
study_duration: Measurements taken preoperatively and at 1, 2, 3 days, and 4 weeks after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify key factors of balance impairment in osteoporotic patients with vertebral fractures (VFs) and investigate correlations between stabilometric parameters and clinical/functional outcomes.
results_summary: The study found no significant correlations between static balance parameters and flexed posture, number, or severity of VFs. Stabilometry measures weakly correlated with age, 20 meters Walking Test, and Barthel Index.
population_specificity: Osteoporotic patients with vertebral fractures (VFs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary effectiveness of a smartphone-enabled home-based exercise therapy (HBET) program compared to walking advice for patients with symptomatic peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found that smartphone-enabled HBET was feasible and aimed to improve 6-minute walking test (6MWT) distance, engagement with the app, and quality of life scores, though final results were pending as enrollment was ongoing.
population_specificity: Symptomatic PAD patients (mean age 66.1 years, 60% female, 87% black) from an inner-city hospital.
effective_dosage: Not specified (daily exercise reminders via smartphone app).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of curcumin to improve muscle recovery and performance following various forms of exercise, including walking.
results_summary: Curcumin supplementation showed benefits in reducing muscle damage, inflammation, oxidative stress, and AGEs, while improving antioxidant capacity and perceived pain/tenderness, though results were inconsistent across studies.
population_specificity: Sedentary to highly active men and women, both young and old.
effective_dosage: Single acute dose to daily dosages for three months (specific amounts not detailed).
study_duration: Ranged from a single dose to three months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fast-track treatment for pertrochanteric fractures preserves patient walking autonomy compared to traditional postoperative care.
results_summary: Fast-track patients showed significantly less loss of walking autonomy (Parker score difference: -1.27, p=0.012) with no significant differences in discharge destination or walking aids, though there was a trend toward returning to initial residence more often.
population_specificity: Patients with isolated A1 or A2 pertrochanteric fractures managed by intramedullary nailing and requiring transfer to Post-acute Recovery (PAR).
study_duration: Postoperative day 1 transfer (fast-track) vs. delayed transfer (non-exposure).

study_goal: To evaluate the safety and feasibility of an aerobic exercise training programme in improving functional capacity for decompensated heart failure patients.
results_summary: The training group showed a statistically significant improvement in functional capacity (54.2 meters increase in walking distance) compared to the control group, with no reported adverse events, indicating safety and efficacy.
population_specificity: Decompensated heart failure patients (mean age 70 years, 20% NYHA class IV, 80% NYHA class III).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether post-meal physical activity, including walking, could improve postprandial glucose, lipids, and markers of oxidative damage and inflammation in adults with features of metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: Post-meal physical activity, including walking, attenuated postprandial glucose, but effects on postprandial lipids and markers of oxidative damage and inflammation were inconclusive.
population_specificity: Adults with features of metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of brisk walking versus Baduanjin exercise on neurocognitive function in long-term hospitalized patients with schizophrenia.
results_summary: Brisk walking did not show significant improvements in processing speed (DSST scores) or visual attention (TMT-A completion times) compared to Baduanjin, which improved logical memory. However, both interventions showed time-related improvements in some cognitive measures.
population_specificity: Long-term hospitalized patients with schizophrenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a peer-led, school-based walking intervention in increasing physical activity levels among adolescent girls.
results_summary: The study is a cluster randomised controlled trial (c-RCT) designed to assess whether a low-cost, peer-led walking intervention can increase physical activity in adolescent girls over a school year, with primary outcomes measured via accelerometer data. Results are pending as the abstract describes the study design rather than final outcomes.
population_specificity: Adolescent girls aged 12-14 years from eighteen schools across the Border Region of Ireland/Northern Ireland.
effective_dosage: 10-15 minute walks before school, at break, and lunch recess, encouraged as frequently as possible each week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether classification-specific treatment (including controlled walking exercises) was more effective than generic treatment for reducing pain, disability, fear-avoidance beliefs, and erector spinae muscle activity in patients with low back pain exhibiting a lumbar extension-rotation pattern.
results_summary: The study found that classification-specific treatment significantly reduced pain intensity, disability, fear-avoidance beliefs, and erector spinae muscle activity during walking compared to generic treatment after a 6-week intervention. The experimental group showed notable improvements, though the decrease in muscle activity was not consistent across all events.
population_specificity: 39 patients with low back pain exhibiting a lumbar extension-rotation pattern.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a "connected behavioral approach" combining cognitive-behavioral training and mHealth technology could increase real-world walking activity and improve walking capacity in individuals with early to mid-stage Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study expects the connected behavioral approach to be more effective than the active control condition in increasing the amount and intensity of real-world walking activity and improving walking capacity, though final results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Individuals with early to mid-stage Parkinson's disease (148 participants).
effective_dosage: Not specified (customized program of goal-oriented walking and strengthening exercises).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if remotely monitoring mobility performance, including walking, could serve as digital biomarkers for cognitive impairment in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found that cognitive-impaired hemodialysis patients spent more time sitting/lying and took fewer daily steps compared to cognitive-intact patients, with significant effect sizes. Mobility performance metrics improved the detection of cognitive impairment, with regression models achieving high discrimination accuracy (AUC up to 0.93).
population_specificity: 69 diabetes mellitus hemodialysis patients (64.1±8.1 years, BMI 31.7±7.6 kg/m²).
study_duration: 24-hour continuous monitoring during a non-dialysis day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of an exercise training program in primary care for patients with mild to moderate COPD.
results_summary: The study found statistically and clinically relevant improvements in exercise capacity (6MWD) and strength (shoulder and handgrip), but no significant differences in breathlessness, quality of life, or daily physical activity.
population_specificity: Patients with mild to moderate COPD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a wellness lifestyle program (WLP) that included walking against a holistic yoga program (HYP) on PTSD symptom severity.
results_summary: The wellness lifestyle program (WLP), which included walking, was less effective than the holistic yoga program (HYP) in reducing PTSD severity, as measured by the CAPS-5. The difference in effectiveness was statistically significant, with a mean difference of -5.4 and an effect size of 0.46.
population_specificity: 209 participants (91.4% veterans; 66% male; 61.7% White) who met diagnostic criteria for PTSD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of physical rehabilitation, including walking, on improving symptoms and quality of life in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients.
results_summary: Physical rehabilitation, including walking, was found to improve muscle function, fitness, balance, and functional movements in MS patients, even those with greater disability. Combined training protocols also enhanced dual motor-cognitive task performance.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS), including those with greater disability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of combined functional training (CFT) on neurotrophic factors (BDNF and IGF-1) and their association with health-related fitness in women with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found no significant change in BDNF levels but observed a significant increase in IGF-1, walking speed, and hand strength in the CFT group compared to controls. A positive correlation was noted between IGF-1 and some fitness components.
population_specificity: Women with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (MS).
effective_dosage: 3 days per week for 8 weeks (rhythmic aerobic exercise, TRX suspension training, elastic band training, and bodyweight training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether promoting physical activity through walking could effectively reduce percentage overweight (%OW) in elementary school children with obesity.
results_summary: The walking group showed a significantly larger reduction in %OW (-4.06 ± 4.84 percentage points) compared to the control group (-1.81 ± 3.64 percentage points), with an adjusted mean difference of -2.18 percentage points (P = 0.002). The intervention also positively influenced the lifestyles of the children's parents.
population_specificity: Elementary school children aged 6 to 12 years with a %OW of ≥20% in Japan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 24-week combined exercise (aerobic and resistance) on hemodialysis efficiency, blood pressure, exercise capacity, and quality of life in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The combined exercise significantly improved hemodialysis efficiency (13.2% increase in sp Kt/V), reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure (8.5 mmHg and 6.5 mmHg, respectively), and increased 6-minute walking distance (43 m or 9.8%), but did not significantly affect quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing hemodialysis
effective_dosage: Moderate-intensity intradialytic combined exercise, three times weekly

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of motion-control shoes versus neutral shoes on knee pain in people with predominantly lateral tibiofemoral osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so no results are reported in the abstract. The primary outcome will measure changes in self-reported knee pain on walking after 6 months of wearing the allocated shoes.
population_specificity: People with painful lateral tibiofemoral OA recruited from the community.
effective_dosage: Participants were instructed to wear their allocated shoes for a minimum of 6 hours per day.

study_goal: The study aimed to explore the effects of microcurrent therapy (MCT) on pain in patients with knee osteoarthritis, comparing different treatment parameters and placebo effects.
results_summary: The study found that MCT significantly reduced evening pain in patients with knee osteoarthritis compared to sham and no intervention groups, with improvements noted in specific KOOS subscales.
population_specificity: Fifty-six patients with knee osteoarthritis (Kellgren-Lawrence Score II or III, 14 male and 38 female, mean age 71.7±7.3 years).
effective_dosage: MCT with 100 µA (group A) and 25 µA (group B), administered in 10 sessions of 30 minutes each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the Active Plus eHealth intervention in improving physical activity, specifically walking, among older adults.
results_summary: The study found that the Active Plus intervention was effective in increasing physical activity, including walking, in the older adult population, demonstrating its potential as a resource-efficient method for promoting PA.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-flow nasal therapy (HFNT) during exercise training in early pulmonary rehabilitation improves outcomes for hospitalized patients with severe acute exacerbation of COPD (AECOPD).
results_summary: The HFNT PR group showed significant improvements in exercise tolerance (6MWD), reduced dyspnea (mMRC), and decreased systemic inflammation (CRP), along with better trends in air trapping (delta IC) and quality of life (CAT) compared to the non-HFNT PR group.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with severe acute exacerbation of COPD (AECOPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of early surgical intervention and multidisciplinary perioperative management for bilateral femoral neck fractures in a dialysis patient, focusing on walking recovery.
results_summary: The patient regained walking ability with a walker three days post-surgery and fully recovered previous walking capacity within six months. Early surgical treatment and multidisciplinary care were deemed effective for favorable recovery.
population_specificity: A 47-year-old female on hemodialysis for polycystic kidney disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if older adults with PAD (with and without T2DM) changed their sedentary behavior during SET and examined the relationship between sedentary behavior changes and SET outcomes.
results_summary: On average, sedentary time did not change after SET, though there was substantial variability. Participants with T2DM experienced greater improvements in claudication onset distance than those without T2DM, but changes in sedentary time did not predict improvements in walking distance.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 72.3 years) with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (PAD), including those with and without type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare three perineal repair suturing techniques after episiotomy or second-degree tearing during normal birth, focusing on reducing pain and improving healing, including pain when walking.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in perineal pain (including pain when walking) among the three suturing groups at 10 days postpartum, with minimal pain reported. The continuous suturing technique was faster than interrupted methods.
population_specificity: Full-term pregnant women over 18 years old who required perineal repair after episiotomy or second-degree tearing during normal birth, attended by midwives.
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 2 and 48 hours, 10 days, 3 months, and 6 months postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare kinematic outcomes during walking in young children with limb loss using Traditional Knee (TK) and Early Knee (EK) prosthetic protocols, alongside a control group of children without amputations.
results_summary: Children in the EK group achieved prosthetic knee flexion during swing phase and showed fewer gait adaptations than the TK group. Walking speed and step length increased with age in the EK group, similar to controls, but this trend was not observed in the TK group.
population_specificity: Children aged 12 months to five years with unilateral limb loss at or proximal to the knee, and age-matched peers without amputations.

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the therapeutic value of ginseng capsules in reducing acute exacerbations and improving quality of life in people with COPD, not Walking.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in COPD exacerbation rates between ginseng and placebo groups, with secondary outcomes showing non-clinically significant improvements. Walking was not a focus of the study.
population_specificity: 200 patients with moderate to very severe COPD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the functional outcomes, complications, and survival rates of patients undergoing surgery for peripheral skeletal metastasis, with a focus on walking ability post-surgery.
results_summary: Post-surgery, 63.5% of patients could walk normally or nearly normally, compared to 28% preoperatively, indicating significant improvement in mobility. However, 6.5% of patients remained unable to walk post-surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral skeletal metastasis (391 patients, predominantly female, with breast, lung, or kidney cancer as primary etiologies).
study_duration: Retrospective analysis spanning 2005 to December 2016 (follow-up duration varied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Tai Chi on plantar loads in individuals with knee osteoarthritis (KOA).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of Tai Chi on plantar loads in KOA patients, only stating that these impacts are not fully understood.
population_specificity: 46 participants with knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify an evidence-based intervention (task-oriented circuit training) to improve mobility in stroke patients and address the research-practice gap in German and Austrian outpatient physical therapy.
results_summary: The study found that task-oriented circuit training led to clinically important improvements in walking distance and speed, with high-quality evidence for these outcomes. However, implementation barriers were identified at the setting, participant, therapist, and outcome measure levels.
population_specificity: People with stroke in Germany and Austria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the demographics, clinical presentation, and hemodynamics data of adult congenital heart disease (CHD) and CHD-related pulmonary hypertension (PH) in Indonesia, including the use of a 6-minute walking test as part of the evaluation.
results_summary: The study found that patients with pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH) had significantly lower 6-minute walking distances, indicating reduced exercise capacity. The 6-minute walking test was used as a functional assessment but was not the primary focus of the study.
population_specificity: Adult patients with congenital heart disease (CHD) and CHD-related pulmonary hypertension (PH) in Indonesia.
study_duration: Data collected from July 2012 to July 2019 (7 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a multimodal exercise program, including walking, on cognitive function and physical performance in elderly people with mobility disabilities.
results_summary: The exercise group showed significant improvements in cognitive function (orientation, memory, language) and physical performance (mobility, walking, balance) compared to the control group. A strong correlation was found between exercise participation and enhanced mobility, walking, and balance performance.
population_specificity: Elderly people (70 participants, aged unspecified) with mobility disabilities.
effective_dosage: Not specified (multimodal exercise program, including walking, conducted for 6 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and compare the effectiveness of two 4-week intensive treadmill training programs (ITAR and CT) for improving walking distance in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: Both ITAR and CT programs showed high adherence, excellent tolerance (no adverse events), and significant improvement in maximum walking distance, comparable to longer conventional programs. The findings support the design of a larger multicenter trial.
population_specificity: In- or out-patients with intermittent claudication (n=38).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare sex-specific gait kinematics between individuals postarthroscopy for FAIS and healthy controls to identify persistent gait impairments.
results_summary: Females with FAIS showed significant differences in pelvic tilt, hip extension, trunk flexion, and pelvic drop compared to healthy females and males with FAIS. Males with FAIS exhibited less pelvic drop and hip adduction than healthy males.
population_specificity: Females and males postarthroscopy for FAIS (average 2.5 years post-surgery) compared to healthy females and males.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the intra-rater and inter-rater reliability of the Clinical Gait Assessment Scale (CGAS) for assessing gait in children with idiopathic toe walking (ITW).
results_summary: The study found robust intra- and inter-rater reliability for the CGAS, particularly for foot and head/trunk movement assessments, while arm movements showed moderate reliability. The obstacle course surface was the most challenging for raters, yielding the highest total impairment score.
population_specificity: Children with idiopathic toe walking (ITW) gait.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility and efficacy of a biobehavioral intervention delivered via telehealth to promote physical activity in veterans with nontraumatic lower-limb amputation.
results_summary: The intervention had high participant retention (90%) and acceptability but low dose goal attainment (10%) and no significant efficacy signals for improving physical activity (step count) or disability outcomes. Safety risks were low, with no significant differences in adverse events between groups.
population_specificity: Military veterans (mean age 65.7 years) with nontraumatic lower-limb amputation.
study_duration: 12 weeks per group (24 weeks total with crossover design).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether persons with spinal cord injury (SCI) could safely and effectively experience walking function using robotic exoskeletons and functional electrical stimulation (FES).
results_summary: Participants with higher lower limb motor scores (LEMS ≥ 10) showed significant improvements in walking function, while those with lower scores (LEMS < 10) did not improve gait function but increased walking velocity and resistance with robotic assistance. The study reported no major complications, with only mild adverse events in a few participants.
population_specificity: Persons with spinal cord injury (SCI), divided into two groups based on lower limb motor scores (LEMS ≥ 10 and LEMS < 10).
effective_dosage: Group A: 20 sessions of Robot-Assisted Gait Training (RAGT) followed by 20 sessions of FES during Overground Gait (FES-OG). Group B: 20 sessions of FES-cycling followed by 20 sessions of overground RAGT.
study_duration: 40 sessions total (20 sessions per intervention phase).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a multifaceted counseling intervention, including physical activity tracking and follow-up calls, in improving physical activity participation and patient outcomes in individuals with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
results_summary: The intervention showed a modest but non-significant increase in moderate/vigorous physical activity (MVPA) and significant improvements in pain and perceived walking habit. Post hoc analysis revealed significant improvements in MVPA and pain specifically in participants with RA.
population_specificity: Individuals with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included education, counseling, Fitbit use, web application feedback, and follow-up calls).
study_duration: 8 weeks of active intervention (with assessments at weeks 9, 18, and 27).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of perioperative inhaled tiotropium on walking distance in the incremental shuttle walking test for COPD patients undergoing esophagectomy.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the intervention on walking distance, only that it was a secondary outcome measured preintervention, preoperative, and postoperative.
population_specificity: Patients with COPD undergoing esophagectomy for esophageal cancer.
study_duration: At least 2 weeks before esophagectomy and continued postoperatively until evaluation (30-44 days after surgery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of active commuting (walking and cycling) on health-related quality of life (HRQoL) and sick-leave days in healthy working adults.
results_summary: Active commuting, including walking, significantly improved several HRQoL subcomponents (physical functioning, mental health, vitality, general health) and reduced sick-leave days in the walking subgroup (IG-PT). The cycling subgroup (IG-C) showed greater HRQoL improvements than the walking subgroup.
population_specificity: Healthy working adults (n=73, age 46±9 years) employed at a university hospital in Salzburg, Austria.
effective_dosage: Not specified (commuting behavior adjusted, partial walking for IG-PT).

study_goal: The abstract does not specifically address the study's goal regarding walking.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to walking.
population_specificity: Not specified in the context of walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether exercise, including walking, reduces the occurrence, severity, or duration of acute respiratory infections (ARIs).
results_summary: Exercise did not reduce the number of ARI episodes or symptom days per episode but reduced the severity of ARI symptoms and the total number of symptom days during the study follow-up period.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18 to 85 years, with a female participant proportion ranging from 52% to 100%.
effective_dosage: Moderate-intensity aerobic exercise (including walking) prescribed at least three times a week for 30 to 45 minutes.
study_duration: Follow-up duration ranged from 1 to 36 weeks (median = 12 weeks).

study_goal: To investigate the safety, feasibility, and potential efficacy of balance training in adults with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The balance training was safe and feasible with no major adverse events. Small, non-significant improvements were observed in ambulatory self-confidence, falls efficacy, and fatigue, with significant between-group differences in self-reported walking confidence and balance change.
population_specificity: Ambulatory adults with cerebral palsy (n=17).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to emphasize the importance of early diagnosis and treatment of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) to ensure normal hip development by walking age.
results_summary: The study highlights that untreated DDH can lead to abnormal hip development if not addressed by walking age, stressing the need for trained health professionals to evaluate and manage infant hip instability early.
population_specificity: Newborns and infants at risk for developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of statins on pain-free walking distance, ankle brachial index, and treadmill exercise time in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found that statins improved pain-free walking distance, ankle brachial index, and treadmill exercise time in PAD patients, while also reducing cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. Statins were shown to decrease the progression and even regress atherosclerotic plaque growth.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD), particularly those with intermittent claudication or leg ischemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to correlate hip-fracture patients' activities of daily living (ADLs) on admission to rehabilitation with their functional outcomes post-rehabilitation, focusing on walking as a key measure.
results_summary: Walking showed the highest efficiency and effectiveness among ADLs post-rehabilitation, with scores of 0.14±0.0 and 64.2±21, respectively. Multivariate analyses identified cognitive function (MMSE) and specific ADLs like bladder control, eating, and bathing as determinants of functional outcomes.
population_specificity: 204 hip-fracture patients admitted to a rehabilitation unit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of ciclosporin and MTX, alone or in combination, in improving clinical features (including walking time) in myositis patients who incompletely responded to glucocorticoids.
results_summary: Patients completing 12 months of treatment showed a 22% improvement in walking time, but intention-to-treat and completer analyses indicated no significant treatment effects for ciclosporin, MTX, or their combination compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Adults with active myositis (by Bohan and Peter criteria) receiving corticosteroids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare oxygenation levels (S(pO2)) and patient satisfaction between a portable oxygen concentrator alone and a combined system (fixed + portable devices) for ambulation in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found that low S(pO2) (<90%) occurred more frequently with the portable concentrator alone (37.1%) compared to the combined system (18.4%). While 43% of subjects preferred the portable system alone, 36% preferred the combined system, and 21% were unsure.
population_specificity: 25 COPD patients (92% men, mean age 72.2 ± 7.4 y, mean FEV1 34.14 ± 12.51% of predicted) from 4 hospitals in Madrid.
effective_dosage: Not specified (oxygenation settings determined at baseline).
study_duration: 1 week per intervention (combined system followed by portable concentrator).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the quality of life and recovery outcomes (including walking without pain) between two surgical techniques (sinotomy vs. surgical excision plus primary closure) for treating pilonidal disease.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in recovery times, with sinotomy patients experiencing shorter hospital stays, quicker return to work, and faster resumption of walking without pain compared to the excision group. No significant differences were observed in complete healing or sport times between the two techniques.
population_specificity: Patients treated for pilonidal sinus (80 total: 40 sinotomy, 40 excision plus primary closure).
study_duration: Retrospective analysis from September 2010 to June 2012; follow-up until complete healing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of protein supplementation on quality of life, physical function, muscle strength, and biochemical blood markers in non-sarcopenic COPD patients undergoing pulmonary rehabilitation.
results_summary: Protein supplementation combined with exercise showed no additional benefits on quality of life, physical function, or muscle strength compared to exercise alone, though improvements in shuttle walk time and some quality-of-life scores were observed over time.
population_specificity: Non-sarcopenic patients (N.=53) with stable moderate to severe COPD, aged 40+ and BMI<30.
effective_dosage: Twice daily protein supplementation (9.3 g of protein/566.4 KJ).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to objectively assess aerobic fitness and physical activity levels in frail and nonfrail elderly and examine their association with frailty.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in aerobic fitness and physical activity levels between frail and nonfrail elderly, with frailty associated with lower peak oxygen consumption and reduced physical activity. These associations remained significant even after accounting for chronic health conditions.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals aged 66 to 86 years, including both frail and nonfrail participants.

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of mental practice (motor imagery training) on motor imagery ability and its influence on gait rehabilitation in sub-acute stroke patients.
results_summary: The motor imagery group showed significant improvements in kinesthetic imagery vividness and walking test results compared to the muscle relaxation group, but no group interaction effect was observed for far transfer outcomes.
population_specificity: 44 patients with gait dysfunction after first-ever stroke.
effective_dosage: Daily mental practice (motor imagery training) for 6 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of spontaneous hemorrhage and venous thrombosis in a hemodialysis patient using LMWH, highlighting the need for monitoring and differential diagnosis via imaging.
results_summary: The study found that a patient on LMWH developed extremity hematoma and venous thrombosis, which resolved with heparin-free hemodialysis, but symptoms recurred upon reintroduction of LMWH.
population_specificity: A 52-year-old male with diabetic nephropathy on maintenance hemodialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an 8-week neuromuscular exercise (NEMEX) program is more effective than optimized analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs in reducing knee-joint load and improving pain and function in people with mild to moderate knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study compared NEMEX therapy with drug use, measuring changes in knee load during walking and secondary outcomes like pain and function. Results will determine if exercise is superior to medication for knee osteoarthritis management.
population_specificity: 100 men and women with mild to moderate medial knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of pharmacological (tizanidine) and physical (locomotor training) interventions on walking function in individuals with incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: Walking speed and endurance improved overall, with no significant differences between interventions. Tizanidine improved endurance in high-functioning participants, while locomotor training enhanced speed and mobility.
population_specificity: Individuals with incomplete motor function loss due to spinal cord injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 12-month moderate-intensity walking program on lipoprotein remodeling in sedentary postpartum Hispanic women.
results_summary: Walkers showed an 11% increase in HDL cholesterol and a beneficial shift toward larger, less atherogenic LDL particles, while nonwalkers experienced a 7% decrease in HDL cholesterol and minimal changes in LDL particle size. The intervention resulted in modest but statistically significant improvements in lipoprotein profiles.
population_specificity: Sedentary postpartum Hispanic women (age 28.2 ± 5.6 y; BMI = 29.3 ± 3.3 kg/m2).
effective_dosage: Target 150 minutes per week of moderate-intensity walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure the physiological cost index (PCI) and comfort walking speed (CWS) in individuals with lower limb amputations and assess their relationship to prosthetic ambulation and stump length.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in PCI and CWS among amputation levels, with higher amputation associated with less energy-efficient walking and lower speed. Crutch-supported prosthetic ambulation increased energy expenditure and reduced walking speed, while stump length impacted PCI and CWS in transfemoral amputees.
population_specificity: 89 individuals with lower limb amputations (excluding PVD) at transfemoral, transtibial, and Syme levels.
study_duration: Five minutes of continuous indoor walking at CWS

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of dynamic response ankle-foot orthoses (DR-AFOs) on walking performance in ambulatory boys with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).
results_summary: The study found that DR-AFO use led to declines in walking speed (10-m walk time) and endurance (6-Minute Walk Distance), with parental reports indicating increased falls in two out of three participants. The study concluded that DR-AFOs are not beneficial for ambulatory boys with DMD.
population_specificity: Boys with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) who are ambulatory.
study_duration: 2 weeks per intervention phase (with a 1-week washout period)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the neurobiological basis of freezing of gait in Parkinson's disease by synthesizing recent insights from research.
results_summary: The study concluded that freezing of gait in Parkinson's disease manifests via a common neural pathway involving inhibitory basal ganglia output and decreased brainstem activity, potentially triggered by dopaminergic depletion and subthalamic nucleus over-activity. These insights may improve diagnostic and therapeutic management of the symptom.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease experiencing freezing of gait.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a cognitive-motor dual-task using auditory cues during treadmill walking improves balance in chronic stroke patients compared to single-task treadmill walking.
results_summary: The dual-task group showed significant improvements in most balance measures (mediolateral and anteroposterior sway velocities) compared to the single-task group, except for anteroposterior sway velocity with eyes open and the Timed Up and Go test at follow-up. All variables improved significantly in the dual-task group post-intervention compared to baseline.
population_specificity: Thirty-seven individuals with chronic stroke in an inpatient rehabilitation setting.
effective_dosage: 15 minutes per session, three times per week, for four weeks, alongside conventional rehabilitation five times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence, symptoms, and complications of tungiasis (a parasitic skin infestation) among schoolchildren in Northern Tanzania, particularly focusing on its impact on walking.
results_summary: The study found that tungiasis caused significant morbidity, with 28 children reporting difficulty walking due to the infestation. Complications included pain, itching, nail dystrophy, deformities, and bacterial superinfections requiring antibiotic therapy.
population_specificity: 62 schoolchildren (ages 6-14) in Qameyu, Northern Tanzania, with suspected tungiasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term safety and efficacy of riociguat in improving exercise and functional capacity, measured by 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) and WHO functional class, in patients with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH).
results_summary: The study found that riociguat maintained a favorable safety profile with no new safety signals and sustained improvements in 6MWD (+51±62 m) and WHO functional class (47% improved, 50% stabilized) for up to 1 year compared to baseline.
population_specificity: Patients with inoperable or persistent/recurrent chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH).
effective_dosage: Individually adjusted up to a maximum of 2.5 mg three times daily.
study_duration: Up to 1 year (interim analysis at 16 weeks in CHEST-1, extended in CHEST-2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a feedback intervention versus standard treatment (including walking) on pain and sensory discrimination in chronic low back pain patients.
results_summary: The control group, which included walking as part of standard treatment, did not show significant improvements in pain-related variables like pain anxiety, vigilance, depression, or cognitive appraisal of pain. The feedback intervention showed better results for self-reported pain and sensory discrimination.
population_specificity: Thirty patients from an outpatient orthopedic rehabilitation unit with chronic low back pain.
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking was part of 6 sessions, each including 2 units of physiotherapy, relaxation, and movement training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and feasibility of aerobic physical exercise (primarily walking) for adults with haematological malignancies.
results_summary: The study found no evidence of differences in mortality between exercise and control groups. Walking improved quality of life, physical functioning, depression, and fatigue, but evidence was inconclusive for anxiety, physical performance, and adverse events.
population_specificity: Adults with haematological malignancies, including acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL), acute myeloid leukaemia (AML), malignant lymphoma, and multiple myeloma, some undergoing stem cell transplantation.
effective_dosage: Various walking intervention programmes with different duration and intensity levels (specifics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether an environmental intervention combining police-patrolled walking and social marketing could increase walking in underserved African-American communities.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity across communities, but walking attendance increased in the social marketing community (from 40 to 400 walkers per month at 9 months, sustaining ~200 walkers through 24 months), while no change occurred in the walking-only community.
population_specificity: Underserved African-American adults (N=434; 62% female; mean age 51±16 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review prognostic markers, including the 6-minute walking test, for idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (IPAH).
results_summary: The study identified the 6-minute walking test as one of several prognostic markers for IPAH, which can help predict patient outcomes and inform treatment planning. However, the abstract does not provide specific data on the effectiveness of walking itself as an intervention.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (IPAH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the role of activin signaling in sporadic inclusion body myositis (sIBM) and evaluate the effects of bimagrumab on muscle volume and function.
results_summary: Bimagrumab increased thigh muscle volume and lean body mass at 8 weeks and improved 6-minute walking distance by 16 weeks, with no serious adverse events reported.
population_specificity: 50 patients with neuromuscular disease (17 with sIBM), with 14 participating in the trial (11 bimagrumab, 3 placebo).
effective_dosage: One dose of bimagrumab (specific amount not stated).
study_duration: 8 weeks of intervention, with a subsequent 16-week observation phase.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in knee sagittal moments in patients with knee osteoarthritis undergoing a biomechanical training program.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in peak knee flexion moment, duration of knee flexion moment, and knee flexion impulse, along with increased walking velocity, pain reduction, and improved functional activity.
population_specificity: Twenty-five female patients with symptomatic medial compartment knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how postoperative walking ability (ADL) in hip fracture patients is influenced by living arrangements, dementia status, and early vs. late mobilization after surgery.
results_summary: Postoperative walking ability was significantly better for patients living at home compared to those in facilities, and dementia patients who mobilized early (within 48 hours) had higher ADL scores than late risers, especially after hemiarthroplasty.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (mostly female, over 65) who underwent hip fracture surgery, including those with dementia and varying living arrangements (home vs. geriatric facilities).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether highly crosslinked polyethylene (HXPE) reduces wear rates compared to conventional polyethylene (CPE) in total ankle replacement systems during walking gait.
