results_summary: HXPE showed a 74% reduction in wear rate compared to CPE, with wear rates of 1.9 ± 0.3 mg/Mc vs. 7.4 ± 1.3 mg/Mc, respectively. The debris morphology trends were consistent with findings in other joint systems.
population_specificity: In vitro samples of semiconstrained, bicondylar total ankle replacement systems.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (wear testing under simulated walking conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of calcifediol and vitamin D3 on gait speed and trunk sway in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Calcifediol improved gait speed by 18% compared to vitamin D3, with a moderate correlation between increased 25(OH)D levels and gait speed improvement. No significant effect was observed on trunk sway.
population_specificity: Healthy postmenopausal women with an average age of 61.5 years and low baseline 25(OH)D levels.
effective_dosage: 20 μg of calcifediol or 20 μg (800 IU) of vitamin D3 per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the responsiveness and criterion validity of the FLS-25 scale for assessing symptoms of lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) in relation to walking capacity and stress test outcomes.
results_summary: The FLS-25 scores correlated significantly with walking capacity, standing time, walking distance, and walking time, confirming its validity and responsiveness to changes after conservative therapy. Changes in FLS-25 scores post-therapy also correlated with improvements in stress test outcomes.
population_specificity: 167 patients with confirmed lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) requiring conservative therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a neuromuscular physiotherapy program (Auf die Beine) combining whole body vibration and intensive therapy blocks in improving motor function and gait in children with spina bifida.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking velocity (0.11 m/s) and mobility (GMFM-66 score increased by 2.54 points) after 6 months of training, though follow-up results were not significant. Decreased contractures and increased muscle function were also observed.
population_specificity: Children with spina bifida (mean age 8.71 ± 4.7 years).
effective_dosage: 6 months of home-based whole body vibration (WBV) with two intensive therapy blocks (13 days initially and 6 days after 3 months).
study_duration: 6 months of active training, with a 6-month follow-up period (total 12 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of behavioral counseling, including walking as part of increased physical activity, for weight loss in overweight and obese patients in primary care settings.
results_summary: The study found that interventions prescribing increased physical activity (e.g., ≥150 minutes a week of walking) alongside reduced energy intake and behavioral therapy produced larger weight loss. More treatment sessions, delivered in person or by telephone, were associated with greater weight loss and higher likelihood of patients losing ≥5% of baseline weight.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese patients recruited from primary care settings.
effective_dosage: ≥150 minutes a week of walking (as part of physical activity).
study_duration: At least 3 months of behavioral counseling, with follow-up ranging from 6 to 24 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of prosthetic hip infection caused by Acremonium and Penicillium species and describe the treatment outcome, including the patient's ability to walk post-revision surgery.
results_summary: The study found that after removal of the infected prosthesis, antifungal therapy, and re-implantation, the patient was able to walk without assistance one year after surgery. The treatment was deemed successful.
population_specificity: A 47-year-old male with liver cirrhosis and bilateral hip hemiarthroplasties.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of population-level interventions, including walking and biking opportunities, to promote physical activity.
results_summary: The study found that community rail-trails, pedometers, and school health education programs were the most cost-effective interventions for increasing physical activity, measured in MET-hours gained per person per day. Improving walking and biking opportunities was highlighted as a cost-effective strategy, though generalizability was limited by the small number of studies.
population_specificity: Wide population groups (primary and preventive interventions, excluding selected groups or individuals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish standardized procedures for conducting field walking tests (6MWT, ISWT, ESWT) to evaluate exercise capacity, prognosis, and treatment response in chronic respiratory diseases.
results_summary: The study confirmed that the 6MWT, ISWT, and ESWT are valid, reliable, and responsive to interventions, though results are sensitive to methodological variations. It emphasized the need for conducting two tests for the 6MWT and ISWT to ensure robust outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic respiratory disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether real-time haptic biofeedback improves compliance with partial weight-bearing instructions compared to conventional methods.
results_summary: Haptic biofeedback significantly improved compliance with partial weight-bearing instructions (22.4±9.1 lb) compared to verbal instruction (60.3±30.5 lb) and bathroom scale training (43.8±17.2 lb). The haptic biofeedback group also showed the lowest percentage of body weight borne (14.5±6.3%), outperforming other methods.
population_specificity: Thirty healthy, asymptomatic participants.
effective_dosage: Participants were instructed to restrict weight bearing to 25 lb (acceptable range: 15-35 lb).

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of exercise interventions, including walking, on overall health-related quality of life (HRQOL) and its domains among cancer survivors who have completed primary treatment.
results_summary: Exercise interventions, including walking, significantly improved overall HRQOL, emotional well-being, and social functioning, while reducing anxiety and fatigue in cancer survivors at 12 weeks.
population_specificity: Cancer survivors who have completed primary treatment.

study_goal: To determine if a 12-week home-based walking program reduces perceived stress and depressive symptoms in individuals with traumatic brain injury (TBI).
results_summary: The study found that both perceived stress and depressive symptoms significantly improved after the walking intervention, suggesting walking is an effective tool for managing these symptoms in TBI patients.
population_specificity: Sixty-nine participants with traumatic brain injury (TBI).
effective_dosage: Not specified (pedometer-tracked steps with weekly goals set by a coach).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of neuromuscular exercise on balance performance and lower limb explosive power in construction workers to reduce fall risk.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in postural sway and backward balancing on a 3-cm beam, with effects likely to most likely practically beneficial, suggesting reduced fall risk.
population_specificity: Healthy middle-aged construction workers (intervention group: N = 20, age = 40.3 years; control group: N = 20, age = 41.8 years).
effective_dosage: 15 minutes of static and dynamic balance and strength exercises each day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of cilostazol on improving walking distances (initial and absolute claudication distances) and reducing mortality and vascular events in patients with stable intermittent claudication secondary to peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: Cilostazol improved both initial and absolute claudication distances compared to placebo, with significant increases in walking distances at dosages of 50 mg and 100 mg twice daily. However, there was no clear evidence of reduced mortality or cardiovascular events, and cilostazol was associated with mild but increased adverse effects like headache and diarrhea.
population_specificity: Patients with stable intermittent claudication secondary to PAD.
effective_dosage: 50 mg, 100 mg, and 150 mg twice daily (cilostazol); 400 mg three times daily (pentoxifylline).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combined use of FBG and PZT sensors for monitoring plantar pressure during walking at low and high speeds.
results_summary: The study found that FBG sensors are suitable for static and slow-walking conditions, while PZT sensors are more accurate for high-speed walking and running, with pressure measurements ranging from 100 to 1000 kPa depending on speed and foot region. The combined use of both sensors enables comprehensive plantar pressure monitoring from static to high-speed conditions.
population_specificity: Healthy male subject

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pain relief from reirradiation of bone metastases improves patients' quality of life and functional abilities, including walking.
results_summary: Responding patients showed improved walking ability and other functional measures, along with enhanced quality of life, as measured by standardized scales. The improvements were consistent but varied in magnitude depending on the assessment tool used.
population_specificity: Patients with pain at sites of previously irradiated bone metastases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of recombinant Idursulfase on walking distance and other clinical parameters in patients with Hunter syndrome.
results_summary: The study found improvements in walking distance, forced vital capacity, liver and spleen volume, and urinary GAG levels, with outcomes varying by disease severity and treatment initiation age.
population_specificity: Patients with Hunter syndrome (severe and attenuated forms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the psychological and performance benefits of walking workstations compared to other workstation types in a workplace setting.
results_summary: Participants using walking workstations reported higher satisfaction and arousal, and lower boredom and stress compared to passive workstations. Cycling workstations showed reduced satisfaction and performance, while BMI and exercise habits did not moderate these effects.
population_specificity: Office workers (n = 180)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical and genetic differences between cancer patients with bone pain (CIBP) and those without (non-CIBP), focusing on pain interference, opioid response, and genetic factors.
results_summary: Patients with CIBP had significantly higher pain interference in walking ability compared to non-CIBP patients, but no specific genetic patterns were identified for CIBP or opioid response.
population_specificity: 2,294 adult cancer patients receiving opioids for moderate or severe pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the use of the Functional Ambulation Performance Score (FAPS) for gait evaluation, addressing misunderstandings and practical limits of its application.
results_summary: The study highlights the FAPS as a valuable tool for quantifying gait at self-selected speeds, but notes its use is sometimes distorted by misconceptions about its composition, calculation, and interpretation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general gait analysis context, likely including clinical populations with gait disabilities).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of exercise training (including walking) on clinical outcomes such as exercise tolerance, functional capacity, and quality of life in patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).
results_summary: The study found that exercise training significantly improved 6-minute walking distance, VO2 peak, work rate, anaerobic threshold, FVC % predicted, dyspnea, quality of life, and 30-second chair-stand performance in IPF patients compared to controls.
population_specificity: Thirty-two IPF patients (aged 68 ± 8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative and postoperative physical exercises, including walking, could reduce postoperative length of stay and early complications in patients undergoing radical cystectomy.
results_summary: The study found that while the intervention improved postoperative mobilization (walking distance) and the ability to perform personal activities of daily living, it did not significantly reduce the length of stay or severity of complications compared to standard care.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing radical cystectomy with lymph-node dissection (n=107, 50 in intervention group, 57 in standard group).
effective_dosage: Standardized preoperative and postoperative strength and endurance exercises, progressive postoperative mobilization (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: The program was initiated 2 weeks before surgery and continued postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-intensity endurance and strength training, including walking, could improve physical fitness, muscle strength, and quality of life in patients recovering from lung cancer surgery.
results_summary: The study found that the exercise group showed significant improvements in peak oxygen uptake, pulmonary function, muscular strength, total muscle mass, functional fitness, and quality of life compared to the control group. The intervention was well tolerated and induced clinically meaningful benefits.
population_specificity: Patients recently operated for lung cancer.

study_goal: The researchers were examining risk factors for stroke, including low walking speed, in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Low walking speed was identified as one of several risk factors for stroke in postmenopausal women, but the study did not specifically evaluate the effects of walking as an intervention.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (27,341 in clinical trials, 93,676 in observational study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of lateral nail avulsion with phenolization (LNAP) versus sleeve surgical techniques for treating ingrown toenails (IGTN) and their impact on walking and daily activities.
results_summary: Both LNAP and sleeve methods showed similar success rates (80-82%) and low recurrence rates (1 patient per group). The sleeve method resulted in shorter postoperative shoe-wearing discomfort and less pain compared to LNAP.
population_specificity: Patients older than 15 years with ingrown toenails (IGTN), predominantly male (87.8%), mean age 27.7 years.
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 1, 3, and 6 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers were evaluating the safety and efficacy of suvorexant, an orexin receptor antagonist, for treating insomnia, including its effects on sleep induction and maintenance.
results_summary: The study found that suvorexant effectively induces and maintains sleep but raised concerns about next-morning somnolence, muscle weakness, weird dreams, sleep walking, and other nighttime behaviors. The FDA and sponsor disagreed on optimal dosing, with final approved doses ranging from 5-20 mg.
population_specificity: Adult and elderly patients with insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the style of walking (depressed vs. happy) affects depression-related memory bias, independent of walking intensity.
results_summary: Participants who walked in a depressed style recalled fewer positive words relative to negative words compared to those who walked in a happy style, suggesting walking style influences memory bias linked to depression vulnerability.
population_specificity: 39 undergraduates (non-clinical group).
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking speed was held constant).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supervised group walking sessions, as part of a broader lifestyle intervention, improved maternal diet and physical activity in overweight or obese pregnant women.
results_summary: The supervised walking group was poorly utilized, and no specific efficacy data for walking alone were reported. The broader lifestyle intervention improved maternal diet and physical activity, but walking's isolated impact was unclear.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with a BMI ≥25 kg/m² and singleton gestation between 10(+0) to 20(+0) weeks.
study_duration: Intervention spanned from recruitment (10-20 weeks' gestation) to 4 months postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the rates of chronic pain and neuropathic pain one year after orthopaedic foot or ankle surgery, and identify associated factors.
results_summary: One year post-surgery, 21% of patients reported moderate-to-severe pain at rest, 43% during walking, and 3% had neuropathic pain. Factors linked to chronic pain included early postoperative pain and revision surgery.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent scheduled orthopaedic foot or ankle surgery at a university hospital between 2009-2011.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intermittent walking could attenuate postprandial blood pressure drops in older people with postprandial hypotension (PPH) after glucose ingestion.
results_summary: Intermittent walking at a usual pace significantly reduced the fall in systolic blood pressure (SBP) after glucose ingestion, though diastolic blood pressure (DBP) still declined. No significant changes in heart rate were observed between control and intervention days.
population_specificity: Older people with postprandial hypotension (PPH).
effective_dosage: Walking 30 meters every 30 minutes for 120 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the reliability, responsiveness, and concurrent validity of the modified gait abnormality rating scale (GARS-M) in quantifying gait abnormalities in individuals with conversion disorder.
results_summary: The study found that GARS-M scores demonstrated good-to-excellent inter- and intrarater reliability, significant improvement post-treatment, and moderate correlation with walking speed, indicating acceptable concurrent validity.
population_specificity: Individuals with conversion disorder manifesting gait disturbances (n=27).
study_duration: Duration of the rehabilitation program not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of supervised progressive resistance training (PRT) combined with unsupervised home-based exercise versus unsupervised home-based exercise alone in improving leg-extension power and other functional outcomes in patients after total hip replacement (THR).
results_summary: Both groups showed improved leg-extension power, with no significant difference between them. However, the intervention group (PRT + home exercise) demonstrated greater improvements in maximal walking speed and stair climb performance compared to the control group (home exercise alone).
population_specificity: Patients with lower pre-operative function scheduled for total hip replacement (THR).
effective_dosage: Intervention group: 5 days/week home-based exercise + 2 days/week PRT; Control group: 7 days/week home-based exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether a preoperative physical activity intervention (PAI) could increase daily moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) in bariatric surgery patients compared to standard care.
results_summary: The PAI group significantly increased both bout-related and total MVPA minutes per day, while the standard care group showed no change. The intervention was effective in increasing preoperative PA levels.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery patients (86.7% women, mean age 46.0±8.9 years, BMI 45.0±6.5 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: Weekly individual face-to-face sessions with tailored behavioral strategies to increase home-based walking exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review advances in the treatment of orthostatic hypotension (OH), focusing on pharmacological options like midodrine and droxidopa.
results_summary: The abstract discusses the prevalence and impact of OH, particularly in patients with uncontrolled hypertension or neurodegenerative conditions, and reviews FDA-approved treatments (midodrine and droxidopa) for managing OH.
population_specificity: Patients with orthostatic hypotension, particularly those with uncontrolled hypertension or neurodegenerative conditions like Parkinson disease, multiple system atrophy, and pure autonomic failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the volume of callosal hyperintensities in older adults with mobility impairment influences gait speed improvement after two different gait interventions (WEBS vs. TC).
results_summary: Both interventions (WEBS and TC) improved gait speed, with the TC group showing slightly greater improvement. Greater genual white matter hyperintensities (WMHs) were associated with smaller gait speed gains in the WEBS group but not in the TC group, suggesting that motor skill-focused rehabilitation may be more beneficial for those with genual WMHs.
population_specificity: Ambulatory adults aged ≥65 years with slow and variable gait (N=44).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of the FAST program (targeting fast functional movements) versus conventional physiotherapy in improving walking balance post-stroke and explore potential mechanisms behind these improvements.
results_summary: The study expects the FAST program to improve walking balance more effectively than conventional physiotherapy, with a focus on investigating mechanisms like muscle activation and response to balance perturbations. Results are pending as the abstract describes a planned trial.
population_specificity: Adults who sustained a stroke within the previous six months.
effective_dosage: Twelve 45-minute 1:1 physiotherapy sessions (either FAST or conventional) over 6–10 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the relationship between step width and gluteus medius (GM) activity during walking, and to assess whether wider steps reduce mechanical demands on hip abductors.
results_summary: The study found that GM activity during walking was significantly influenced by step width, with 47% higher activity in Wide steps and 24% lower activity in Narrow steps compared to Normal walking. The results suggest that increased step width does not reduce hip abductor demands but may instead be a response to decreased gait balance.
population_specificity: Fourteen young, uninjured adults.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking conditions: Normal, Narrow, Medium, and Wide steps).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an overload exists in the medial aspect of protrusio joints during walking and how joint-preserving procedures affect load distribution.
results_summary: The study found that protrusio hips exhibited a 54% higher medial overload during walking compared to normal hips. Acetabular reorientation reduced stresses by up to 25%, while isolated rim trimming worsened the overload.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe pincer impingement (acetabular protrusio) and dysplasia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the under-recognition of upper extremity dysfunction in multiple sclerosis (MS) compared to walking impairment and to evaluate available assessment tools for UE function in MS.
results_summary: The study found that UE dysfunction is prevalent in MS but under-recognized due to limited validated assessment tools. Current measures, though useful, have limitations and require further validation for MS-specific use.
population_specificity: Individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if sit-stand workstations could reduce sitting time and increase standing and walking time among office workers.
results_summary: The study found that using sit-stand workstations significantly reduced sitting time at work by 73 minutes/day and increased standing time by 65 minutes/day, with a notable decline in total sitting time (-80 minutes/day).
population_specificity: Office workers in Sydney, Australia (86% female, mean age 38 ± 11 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved using sit-stand workstations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the accuracy of ED-based fall risk factors and stratification instruments in predicting future falls among geriatric adults.
results_summary: The study identified six fall predictors (past falls, living alone, use of walking aid, depression, cognitive deficit, and more than six medications) and found one screening instrument sufficiently accurate to identify low-risk geriatric ED patients for falls.
population_specificity: Geriatric adults aged 65 years and older assessed in emergency departments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility and acceptability of a dog walking intervention based on social cognitive theory for promoting physical activity.
results_summary: The intervention group significantly increased weekly dog walking (79.3 minutes) compared to the control group (19.4 minutes). Participants found the intervention emails easy to understand but were less convinced they encouraged increased dog walking.
population_specificity: Middle-aged (mean 45.7 years), predominantly Caucasian, obese (mean BMI 30.0) dog owners.

study_goal: To determine if haptic cues from a moving handrail can improve gait symptoms (e.g., speed, stride length) in people with Parkinson's disease compared to using a banister or unassisted walking.
results_summary: The moving handrail increased gait speed by 16% and stride length by 10% in PD participants without altering stride or double-support duration, while a banister slowed gait. Haptic cues from the moving handrail improved gait control better than static banister cues.
population_specificity: People with Parkinson's disease (n=16) and healthy age-matched controls (n=16).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the consistency of three methods (participant, clinical rater, and computer algorithm) for assessing turn entry and exit points during walking in healthy older adults.
results_summary: The three assessment methods showed overall consistency (68-100% agreement), but participants identified turn exit points earlier than the algorithm and clinical rater. Differences in turn determination between the algorithm and rater were significant at turn entry points but not at exit points. Greater discrepancies in assessing turn exit points were linked to worse visuospatial performance.
population_specificity: Nineteen non-demented and nondisabled older adults (mean age 75.40 ± 5.52 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and sustainability of lifestyle physical activity (light-moderate intensity) and structured exercise (moderate-vigorous intensity) approaches for increasing physical activity in adults with intellectual disability (ID).
results_summary: The study compared short-term (3-month) and long-term (9-month) outcomes of two physical activity interventions against a usual-care control group, measuring aerobic fitness, energy expenditure, and everyday physical activity, among other secondary outcomes. Results will determine which approach is more effective and sustainable for increasing physical activity in adults with ID.
population_specificity: Adults with intellectual disability (ID) aged 18-55.
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions involved lifestyle physical activity or structured exercise, but exact dosages/frequencies not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a rare case of heterotopic ossification (HO) in bilateral hips and knees following encephalitis, which impaired walking, and to describe the treatment approach.
results_summary: The patient regained joint mobility after surgical resection of HO, ligament reconstruction, and 8 weeks of Celecoxib therapy, with no recurrence observed on follow-up imaging.
population_specificity: A 47-year-old man with HO in bilateral hips and knees following encephalitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a self-efficacy-based exercise intervention, including walking and calf muscle exercises, improves healing rates and self-management in adults with venous leg ulcers.
results_summary: The study evaluated a 12-week individualized walking and exercise program, supported by behavioral coaching and goal setting, but the abstract does not provide specific outcome data on healing rates or functional improvements.
population_specificity: Adults with venous leg ulcers recruited from three clinical sites in Australia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (individualized program, encouraged self-monitoring of weekly steps).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether financial incentives and peer networks delivered via eHealth technologies could increase walking among older adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in walking goal achievement between the intervention groups (Financial Incentive, Peer Network, Combined) and the Comparison group during the 16-week intervention. During the 8-week follow-up, the Peer Network group performed worse than the Comparison group, while the other interventions showed no significant difference.
population_specificity: Older adults with computer and Internet access
effective_dosage: Daily walking goals (specific step count not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) during rehabilitation exercises reduces pain and improves function, specifically during walking and range-of-motion activities, in patients after total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: TENS reduced postoperative pain during active knee extension and fast walking compared to standard care, but no significant difference was found between TENS and placebo-TENS. Patients with low anxiety and pain catastrophizing showed greater pain reduction with TENS, but the effect diminished by 6 weeks.
population_specificity: 317 participants after primary, unilateral total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
effective_dosage: TENS used 1-2 times per day at an average of 42 mA.
study_duration: Postoperative period up to 6 weeks after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a low-cost, home-based pulmonary rehabilitation program involving walking on exercise capacity and quality of life in COPD patients.
results_summary: The home-based pulmonary rehabilitation group showed significant improvements in the 6-minute walk test (65 m increase) and treadmill endurance test (316.6 ± 81.8 m increase), along with improved quality of life scores, while the control group showed no changes.
population_specificity: Subjects with COPD (FEV1 = 62.4 ± 10.7% of predicted, aged 62.4 ± 10.7 years).
effective_dosage: Walking for 40 min/day, 5 days/week, plus stair climbing (15 min) and arm exercises (15 min).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether interval walking training (IWT) could prevent muscle atrophy and aerobic capacity impairment in female patients who had undergone total hip arthroplasty (THA).
results_summary: IWT increased knee flexion force by 23% on the operated side and 14% on the non-operated side, while VO₂peak and anaerobic threshold improved by 8% and 13%, respectively, compared to the control group. The study concluded that IWT might be an effective home-based training regimen for THA patients.
population_specificity: Female patients (~60 years old) who had undergone THA more than 2 months prior.
effective_dosage: 60 minutes of fast walking at >70% peak aerobic capacity (VO₂peak) per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association of small-dense LDL particles with the outcome of balloon angioplasty in patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (PAD), focusing on improved walking distance and absence of restenosis.
results_summary: The study found that patients with lower proportions of small-dense LDL particles and larger LDL size had better outcomes, including improved walking distance and absence of restenosis, after percutaneous revascularization.
population_specificity: Patients with angiographically documented PAD of the lower extremities scheduled for lower limb revascularization (mean age 68.6±9.9 years, 53% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of exercise programs on gait performance and assess the overall quality of evidence for adults ambulating with leg prostheses.
results_summary: The study found that exercise programs, including supervised walking, muscle strengthening, balance exercises, and functional training, demonstrated small to large effect size improvements in self-selected gait speed. Functional exercise programs were more effective than supervised walking, but the overall quality of evidence was low.
population_specificity: Adults with lower limb amputations using prostheses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and content of early rehabilitation, including walking, for patients with acute aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (aSAH).
results_summary: Early rehabilitation, including walking, was feasible from the first day after securing the aneurysm, with no serious adverse effects. Poor-grade patients received more rehabilitation time, and at discharge, 67% of poor-grade and 78% of good-grade patients achieved walking mobilization.
population_specificity: Patients with acute aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (aSAH), categorized as poor-grade (WFNS 3, 4, 5) or good-grade (WFNS 1, 2).
effective_dosage: Not specified (rehabilitation time varied by patient grade: median 412 min for poor-grade, 240 min for good-grade).
study_duration: Varied by patient condition, with out-of-bed mobilization achieved by day 3 for good-grade and day 7 for poor-grade patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a pedometer-based physical activity enhancement programme could effectively improve physical activity levels and quality of life in COPD patients compared to standard activity encouragement alone.
results_summary: The pedometer group showed significantly greater improvements in daily step count, quality of life (SGRQ and CAT scores), and 6-minute walking distance compared to the control group. The results suggest that pedometer use can effectively enhance physical activity and quality of life in COPD patients.
population_specificity: COPD patients (mean age 68.7±8.5 years, 60.8% male, FEV1 66.1±19.4%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety, effectiveness, adherence, and acceptance of home-based telemonitored Nordic walking in heart failure patients, including those with cardiovascular implantable electronic devices.
results_summary: Nordic walking significantly improved functional capacity (VO2peak), workload duration, six-minute walking test distance, and quality of life in heart failure patients, with no adverse events or hospitalizations reported. The control group showed no favorable results.
population_specificity: Heart failure patients (NYHA II-III) with left ventricular ejection fraction ≤40%, including those with cardiovascular implantable electronic devices.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility of using remote sensing to provide quantitative feedback on walking performance and motivate greater practice in stroke rehabilitation patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in daily walking time or walking speed between groups receiving basic feedback versus augmented feedback. Notably, 30% of participants decreased their walking time during rehabilitation, and overall walking time was modest.
population_specificity: Inpatient stroke rehabilitation patients from 16 centers across 11 countries.
study_duration: 15 months (enrollment period), individual intervention duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if mobilizing patients shortly after lumbar disc surgery using a walking frame was feasible and safe, with the goal of reducing postoperative complications and shortening hospitalization.
results_summary: Patients in the walking group mobilized earlier, required fewer painkillers and less oxygen on the first postoperative day, but length of stay and complication rates were similar to the control group. The study suggests early walking may be feasible and safe without increasing complications.
population_specificity: Patients recovering from lumbar disc surgery (n=22, 11 per group).
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking with a frame, porter, and nurse from postanesthesia care unit to general ward).
study_duration: Intervention occurred shortly after surgery; follow-up lasted three weeks.

study_goal: To assess the long-term effects of radial shock wave therapy (RSWT) on pain and muscle hypertonia in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients with ankle extensor muscle hypertonia.
results_summary: RSWT reduced muscle tone one week after the last session and decreased pain at all follow-up evaluations, with no effect on spinal excitability. Placebo treatment showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: 34 patients with multiple sclerosis suffering from painful hypertonia of ankle extensor muscles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess changes in the Barthel Index (BI), including walking-related activities, in elderly patients after dermatologic surgery for non-melanoma skin cancer.
results_summary: The study found minimal changes in BI scores after surgery, with slight variations in activities like walking stairs, but overall, daily living activities were not significantly affected.
population_specificity: Patients aged 80 years and older diagnosed with non-melanoma skin cancer.
study_duration: Assessments were conducted before surgery, 7 days after, and 30 days after.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immediate and late (6-week) biomechanical effects of laterally wedged insoles and valgus knee braces on gait in patients with early medial knee osteoarthritis, and whether subgroups (compliance, BMI, OA status) influenced outcomes.
results_summary: The study found a modest 4% reduction in peak knee adduction moment and moment arm at baseline with insoles, but no sustained effect after 6 weeks. Braces showed no biomechanical benefits. Subgroup analysis revealed no differences based on obesity, OA stage, or clinical response.
population_specificity: Patients with early medial knee osteoarthritis and varus alignment (n=80).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the biomechanical performance of the C-Brace orthosis compared to conventional leg orthoses during walking, ramp descent, and stair descent.
results_summary: The C-Brace allowed nearly natural stance phase knee flexion during level walking and closer-to-normal swing phase knee flexion compared to conventional orthoses. All patients could ambulate ramps and stairs using a step-over-step technique with the C-Brace, unlike with conventional orthoses.
population_specificity: Six patients with paretic or paralyzed lower limb muscles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral supplementation with vitamin C, vitamin E, zinc gluconate, and selenomethionine could improve physical performance (including walking) in patients with FSHD.
results_summary: The supplement improved maximal voluntary contraction and endurance limit time of the quadriceps but had no significant effect on the two-minute walking test. Antioxidant defenses were enhanced, and oxidative stress markers were reduced.
population_specificity: Adult patients with facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (FSHD) (n=53).
effective_dosage: 500 mg vitamin C, 400 mg vitamin E, 25 mg zinc gluconate, and 200 μg selenomethionine once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore participation restrictions in valued life activities, including walking, among patients with early rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: The study found that patients with early RA experienced participation restrictions in activities like walking the dog, highlighting dilemmas in domestic life and mobility. These restrictions were often interconnected with other challenges in daily activities.
population_specificity: 48 patients aged 20-63, three years post-RA diagnosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the functional outcomes and cost-effectiveness of two ligament reattachment techniques (suture anchor and suture bridge) for the modified Brostrom procedure in treating chronic ankle instability.
results_summary: Both techniques showed similar functional outcomes, with no significant differences in AOFAS score, FAOS, Karlsson score, Sefton grade, or stress radiographs. The suture bridge technique had lower cost-effectiveness due to additional medical expenses.
population_specificity: 45 amateur athletes under 30 years of age with chronic ankle instability.
study_duration: Follow-up period of more than 2 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and safety of bilateral intramuscular administration of cytokine-mobilized CD133+ cells in ambulatory patients with refractory critical limb ischemia (CLI).
results_summary: The study found that the administration of CD133+ cells was safe with no differences in serious adverse events between treatment and control groups. Non-significant trends toward improved amputation-free survival, 6-minute walk distance, and quality of life were observed in the treatment group, but poor mobilization efficiency and high cell senescence suggested futility in this approach.
population_specificity: Ambulatory patients with refractory critical limb ischemia (CLI).
effective_dosage: 50-400 million sorted CD133+ cells delivered into both legs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a home-exercise program (NEXT Step), supervised exercise, and light resistance training on walking performance, vascular function, and inflammation in patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: Both the NEXT Step home program and supervised exercise significantly improved claudication onset time, peak walking time, 6-minute walk distance, daily ambulatory activity, and calf muscle oxygen saturation. The NEXT Step program also improved vascular function and inflammation markers, while the supervised exercise did not.
population_specificity: Symptomatic peripheral artery disease (PAD) patients.
effective_dosage: Intermittent walking to mild-to-moderate claudication pain (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an online-delivered physical activity intervention for increasing regular walking among rural Australian adults.
results_summary: The study protocol describes a randomized controlled trial to assess the impact of an online intervention on physical activity levels, health measures, psychological well-being, diet quality, and correlates of physical activity, with outcomes measured at multiple follow-up points.
population_specificity: Insufficiently active adults aged 18 to 70 years living in rural areas of South Australia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (step goals individualized based on reported steps, affect, and perceived exertion).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop algorithms for mapping between the Roland Morris Questionnaire (RMQ) scores and health utilities derived from EQ-5D or SF-6D to inform economic evaluations of low back pain interventions.
results_summary: The study developed accurate models for predicting EQ-5D and SF-6D health utilities from RMQ scores, with the best-performing models being a beta regression for EQ-5D and a finite mixture model for SF-6D. These models provide a basis for estimating health utilities when direct measures are unavailable.
population_specificity: 701 patients with low back pain from the Back Skills Training Trial.
study_duration: Data collected at baseline, 3, 6, and 12 months post-randomization.

study_goal: To determine whether adding a single, 15-minute walk on the day of surgery to a fast-track rehabilitation protocol would reduce knee pain and improve knee function after total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: Adding an additional 15-minute walk did not increase pain but also did not improve functional recovery. Pain scores and functional outcomes were similar between the intensive and standard protocol groups.
population_specificity: Patients with primary osteoarthrosis after TKA.
effective_dosage: One or two 15-minute walks on the day of surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the benefits of exercise training for people with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and determine optimal exercise prescriptions.
results_summary: Exercise training significantly improved aerobic capacity (peak VO2), pain-free and total walking distances, and graded treadmill performance in PAD patients, with arm cranking and mild-pain threshold training showing particular benefits. No significant improvements were observed in ankle-brachial index (ABI) or flow-mediated dilatation (FMD).
population_specificity: Individuals with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise prescriptions varied by study).
study_duration: Not specified (duration varied by included RCTs).

study_goal: To compare the short- and long-term benefits of FES-assisted walking therapy versus a non-FES exercise program on gait and balance improvements in individuals with chronic incomplete traumatic SCI.
results_summary: The intervention group showed improvement in the SCIM mobility sub-score compared to the control group, but other outcome measures showed similar improvements in both groups. Walking speed, endurance, and balance improved in both groups post-therapy, with most participants retaining gains at follow-ups.
population_specificity: Individuals with traumatic and chronic (≥18 months) motor incomplete SCI (level C2 to T12, ASIA Impairment Scale C or D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the validity and test-retest reliability of a robotic hippotherapy system by comparing its movements with those of a real horse.
results_summary: The study found an excellent correlation in time-to-peak acceleration between the robotic and real horses (R²=0.997) but little correlation in X-axis acceleration (R²=0.177). The real horse produced nearly five times greater acceleration than the robotic horse.
population_specificity: Individuals with neurological or musculoskeletal impairments.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the benefit and safety of NSAIDs (including COXIBs) for treating acute gout, not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that NSAIDs and COXIBs were similarly effective for pain and swelling in acute gout, with COXIBs associated with fewer adverse events. Glucocorticoids and NSAIDs showed comparable pain relief and safety profiles.
population_specificity: Participants with acute gout (2200 total across included trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the characteristics and predisposing factors of ulnar fractures in patients with long-term bisphosphonate therapy, particularly focusing on the role of walking aids and repetitive stress.
results_summary: The study found that elderly female patients using walking aids after 7 to 15 years of bisphosphonate therapy were prone to atraumatic, non-comminuted proximal ulnar fractures, especially in the dominant limb. These fractures exhibited features similar to atypical femoral fractures, suggesting a possible link to suppressed bone remodeling due to bisphosphonates.
population_specificity: Elderly female patients with long-term bisphosphonate therapy who used walking aids.

study_goal: To investigate the effectiveness of functional electrical stimulation (FES) in improving lower limb function and ability in activities of daily living (ADL) for early stroke patients.
results_summary: FES combined with standard rehabilitation significantly reduced spasticity (CSS) and improved lower limb function (FMA), balance (BBS, PASS), and ADL ability (MBI) after 2 and 3 weeks of treatment. The FES group showed progressive benefits over time compared to standard rehabilitation alone.
population_specificity: Early stroke patients (n=37, randomized into two groups).
effective_dosage: FES delivered for 30 minutes per session, 5 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of intrathecally administered triamcinolone-acetonide (TCA) on clinical parameters, including maximum walking distance, in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found that TCA treatment significantly improved maximum walking distance, spasticity, and disability in MS patients. Bladder function improved in every seventh patient, and physiotherapy contributed to the overall improvement of clinical parameters.
population_specificity: 54 patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) experiencing spasticity and other symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to outline the components of physical activity interventions, particularly walking, and assess their effectiveness in increasing physical activity among patients with COPD.
results_summary: The study found that walking-based interventions showed significant between-group differences in increasing physical activity in 7 out of 16 studies, suggesting potential efficacy for COPD patients. However, intervention components varied widely, and not all studies demonstrated consistent benefits.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
study_duration: Varied across studies (not specified in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different footwear (normal walking shoes, standard sandals, and custom-made sandals with a metatarsal pad) on walking distance, symptom onset, and plantar-pressure distribution in patients with central metatarsalgia.
results_summary: Custom-made sandals with a metatarsal pad significantly increased walking distance and time until symptom onset compared to normal walking shoes and standard sandals, while also reducing plantar-pressure in the forefoot region.
population_specificity: 22 patients (42 feet) with central metatarsalgia.
